description: Amazing carnitas burrito:) I inhaled it!!! It is one of the best Mexican eateries in sf. I'll be back to try something different. It's also nice because it closes late and a great place for a quick bite to eat.
author: V M.

description:
I live right up the road.  I have to say when they first opened I was skeptical, but they have proved me wrong time and time again.  First, I want to tell y'all about the special "mojado" option..aka wet burrito. The chille verde, amazing, is perfect when eaten in mojado style, perfectly tender pork, best chille verde I've had in a while.  So on to the burrito I had tonight, steak and shrimp, simple, but executed so well.  Thank you, el Rancho Grande, y'all are a Fantastic addition to the hood.  

See y'all soon
author: Patrick W.

description:
Late night spot to stroll over to after leaving The Independent. 

For us in the IE it is just normal ol' "Albertos" food. They took a credit card and was open; at the time that was all that mattered.
author: Rebekah S.

description: Wow Mexican food!! The food was great that you didn't expect even though the few table they have. This place was really busy because it was really close to bus stop and people stop by and buy. One thing they need to improve the buzzer who needs to clean all the time because we are customer not clean your table. I hope you alert your surroundings and we don't want disappointed. I'll come back and grab to go when I visit again SF.
author: Sharmaine Q.

description: Simply an amazing taqueria. The service is fast and friendly and the food is consistently delicious. The chicken Mexican salad is always made fresh and with high-quality ingredients. It's also pretty large so it's a great value. Super burrito is also must try.
author: Austin S.

description:
I was only in the market for a burrito at El Rancho Grande because the nearby Candybar had a 1.5 hour wait and I needed a late night meal while I waited.  The carnitas super burrito satisfied my ability to fill myself and the place didn't have a wait at all, but for many reasons, I wouldn't choose to come here under normal circumstances for an actual lunch or dinner with other people. 

Why?

- The guacamole tasted like that fake pre-packaged guac you buy at Safeway but tasted even more watered down; I wouldn't know it was guac unless I read that in the super burrito description
- The carnitas tasted like bland shredded pork, it's not at all what you envision that carnitas is actually supposed to taste like 

Those two reasons alone make it that you should find another taqueria or burrito joint if you have the time and flexibility to get there.
author: Albie F.

description:
If you drive by in a hurry, you'll miss it. Had the luck to dine here for a late dinner the other night, and the burrito was so good I wished I had the foresight to wear sweats. It's that damned good.

If you want a take-out meal, they're good for it. If you dine in, enjoy. I had the carne asada burrito and it felt like the best mouth sex.
author: Aida N.

description:
Pretty standard cheap mexican joint that is down the street from me. Burritos and tacos are on par with similar style joints around town. Been coming here more often because I think their nachos are better than those of Little Chihuahua's. The staff here is super nice and always throw in an extra bag of chips, even if you just order a drink. Salsa bar is pretty tasty, but I wish they had more pickled veggies.

If you want mexican but don't want to deal with the crowd at LC - I recommend you come here. I'm always in and out within 10 minutes of ordering (to go).
author: John N.

description: Hands down best carnitas burrito I have experienced in SF, maybe anywhere.  From the perfectly golden crusted tortilla to the perfect ratio of beans:rice:meat:cheese, to the flavor and texture of the meat, I give it a motha f&%$in 10!
author: Joe M.

description:
go to late night spot in the neighborhood. I wouldn't recommend eating dinner or lunch there but post bars who doesn't want a california burrito?

if such a person exists i don't want to meet them.
author: Misha T.

description: I love the tacos here one of my favorites spots to go there I always get the carnitas ! I recommen this place
author: Remysbarbie M.

description: While the tacos here are not as cheap as those in LA, they are filled with meat! I had the carnitas and the carne asada regular tacos. They were delish! It was tender, moist, and flavorful. Nom nom nom.
author: Melissa T.

description: El Rancho Grande is very good Mexican food. It doesn't re-invent the wheel, but it's always enjoyable. Papalote is similarly good (and arguably better), but there are some areas where El Rancho is superior: they're quicker and they have better hours, to name a few.
author: Erik B.

description:
I usually go to Little Chihuahua but for a super burrito the total usually comes to $11. I wanted to check out this place because it had good reviews and is cheaper. I was a bit skeptical because I read it was low food quality, but after eating it I give it a thumbs up. 

The only drawback is that it's definitely greasier than most other burrito places I've been to in the city. They have the standard salsas (pico, green, red) plus they have lime wedges which is a plus. The total comes to $8.30 for a super burrito.
author: Ted B.

description:
$3.75 for Fried fish tacos that are fan-fricking-tastic and great super burritos too!

I recommend the al pastor for pork-eaters.  It's really, really good.

Pretty fast service and clean.  I've eaten there 2 times in the last 24 hours.
author: Lucas W.

description:
I like El Rancho Grande, because it's close (to me at least!), quick, open late, and they pile on the meat. Skimpy tacos don't happen here. Also, the salsa bar is muy yum. 

El Rancho Grande isn't my favorite favorite #1 taqueria, but, it definitely has a place in my heart.
author: Paige C.

description: They boil the steak/beef for their super burrito. It's nothing more super than a regular burrito(size). 1 star for staying open late, we came from a 15 mile hike and burnt out. Anything sounded good or should of been good, today being memorial weekend on a Sunday night we settled for this hole because of our drive straight to Yosemite after. The food was bland, boiled, and the restaurant as a whole looks unsanitary. There was a dude that was taking a piss outside of the front door next to a bum sitting outside when we were leaving. The female behind the register was rude and impatient even though my buddies and I were the only one in line. Please stay away, I'm only praying the food was bad and not going to affect us the morning after. I don't know if I came on a shitty night or this is how it is  on the daily but I recommend everyone to stay away. The salsa bar was a disaster, I was hoping yelp would of hooked me up but this place is a fail.
author: rome r.

description: This is by far the best Mexican restaurant in a 5 mile radius. The quality keeps improving and the staff is always smiling and friendly. I always get the Milanesa plate, Caldo de Pollo and Pollo Asado Burrito, satisfaction guaranteed! Also, even though the only open at 10am, their Huevos Rancheros is incredibly delicious and great bfast pick.
author: Andre F.

description: when i lived in the area, this used to be my go-to taqueria. yes, that other uber-popular place down the street gets all the attention, and they do have good, but that's extreme white people Mexican food. this place, on the other hand, aims a little bit closer to what you might get in the Mission. delicious, filling, and inexpensive.
author: Ronny K.

description:
Good, Cheap, Convenient and the salsa bar is a plus!
I would recommend the grilled veggie burrito and the tacos
The burger is also surprisingly good for being from a Mexican restaurant!
Pass on the nachos- they get soggy really quickly
This is more of a grab and go place in my opinion but they do have beer and tv if you want to eat there
The service is always fast and friendly and they are open late.
author: Deja B.

description: Chips were cold. I had a veggie burrito and it wasn't really different... The tomato sauce was there for hours and looked old. I really enjoyed the fried onions though.. Orchata tasted great! And also enjoyed the soccer game on their TV
author: Enrique R.

description:
Carne Asada Quesadilla is really good and HUGE, you can definitely split it! The staff is super friendly. I've been going here since I moved in the Neighborhood (one year) and it's very consistent. 
Minus 1 star because I don't like the chips they use for nachos or as a side with salsa.
author: Mak T.

description:
Hey dude.

Favorite childhood ranch: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qApK1ifOW7I

Favorite adult ranch: Here thanks to the grand size and taste of the tortas and burritos.

Burrito overflowed with grilled chicken and black beans barely contained in a wheat tortilla.

Torta overflowed with BBQ chicken (perfect hint of the sauce), black beans and lettuce. Enough to so it became two meals.

Condiment bar includes free grilled onions. Yes please.

Saddle up (or Muni up) and come on by.
author: Jason B.

description: Worst Mexican food ever.  They should be embarrassed to put the word taqueria on their sign.
author: C L.

description:
Just opened a few days ago.  I was little surprised to see it opening with Papalote, Green Chile, Nopalito, and Little Chihuahua all within 5 blocks, but really, a no-frills Taqueria is exactly what this stretch needs, and looks like these guys are going to deliver.

I stopped in at 3 today and they were still busy from late lunchers like myself.  Thinking the burritos would be disappointing compared to Little Chihuahua, I instead went with a super steak quesadilla.  While it did have a non standard presentation, it was absolutely delicious and filling for $8 even after tax.  Well worth the short wait.  

Looking forward to coming back and trying more of their menu, which is much more extensive than one would assume.
author: John H.

description:
Hoping for a quick way to get some great nacho's I decided to hit up the new burrito joint down the street.

The quality of their food is way below anything I would expect for $8 nachos. They didn't put ANY cheese on my nachos. Used sloppy refried beans - didn't bother to ask if I wanted black beans. Then the kicker was I had to spit out 4 chunks of gritty-fatty al pastor that was inedible.

I also had to remind the girl to give me my bottle of coke when she handed me my food. Even after she looked directly at the receipt while calling out my order.

Not going back - Little Chihuahua, Papalote and GCK are only another 2-3 blocks away.
author: Ross H.

description:
Maybe it's because I live around the corner and I'm a regular that they always take care of me.... but this place has never dissapointed me!

Is it the best 'taco shop' i've ever been to? I think not, that being said it's reliable cheesy greasy mexican that you're looking for on those recovery days! 

The carnitas super burrito is my weapon of choice! I have never gotten sick and never been served cold food... and I eat here ALL THE TIME! Get in there and try it out for yourself
author: Kevin D.

description: This is the best burrito spot that I've tried in nopa. I can't resist their California burrito. And their salasa and chili's are a hell of a lot better the little Chihuahua.
author: Beni R.

description: Great place, good cheap food and a friendly staff. Quesadillas are a must and burritos are huge!
author: Miguel O.

description: Best Tex-Mex place on Dvisadero (within walking distance of Haight).  I order burritos here at least once a week and have started to explore the rest of their menu. I think there are a few places closer to me (Little Chihuahua) but find the food at El Rancho to be a better price to taste ratio.
author: Kevin Y.

description:
Stopped in here for a very quick bite before a tat session and got the single steak taco. It wasn't too bad - 2 corn tortillas, heaped with steak and topped with hot sauce and cilantro. Slightly on the salty side but overall it was good and came with free chips!

I'd say this is a really good place to stop at if you're in a hurry and just want to grab something small and fast.  I didn't have to wait long for the taco and probably could have ordered 2!  They have a pretty big menu so next time I'm in the area I may try something different.
author: Mercy D.

description:
Although I'm not much of a carnivore, every now and then I feel a certain craving for the noblest cut of the cow--the tongue. Back when I was in Japan I found out that the most delicious and the only way to cook this oft-overlooked part of the cow is to peel off the thick hide from the tongue thus revealing the soft juicy meat under it, perhaps season it with a little salt and then grill the gorgeous thin cuts of meat over a charcoal fire. I was very disappointed to find that the tongue never made it as a staple cut in the American beef diet, but my disappointment was set aback when I found out that the pan-Americans and the magical restaurants that have so become ubiquitous to American cities known as "Taquerias" usually carry my preferred cut of beef as part of their delicious burrito menu. This all changed tonight when I visited El Rancho Grande.

Fueled partially by an initiative to explore my immediate surroundings a little thoroughly and partially by a drunken escapade, I decided to try out the taqueria that's exactly two and a half blocks away from where I live. My first impressions of the establishment was no different from any other Taquerias I've visited all around California; little cashier's booth under neath a giant menu conveniently located aside the actual "cooking area", seats lined up across the wall with a TV playing Mexican soaps/futbol on telemundo. So assuring myself that this experience would not be any different from my usual frequentings, I decided to order my favorite cut of beef wrapped around a tortilla stuffed with rice, beans, sour cream, diced tomatoes and onion and guacamole. How can you possibly mess this up, right?

Well that's where I was wrong. I'm not a burrito scientist, but the first sign of a poorly made burrito can be observed through the color of the tortilla; the tortilla was toasted/browned--to date I've never had a single positive experience with burritos when the tortilla was (nearly) burnt to a crisp. My next grievance with ERG's burrito is that the queso they used overpowered almost every flavor the burrito had to offer--if I wanted a cheesy filling Mexican dish wrapped in a tortilla I would have ordered a quesadilla. 

My last and final grievance with RG's lengua burrito is that it managed to capture every reason why white people don't usually eat this cut of meat; they somehow managed to overboil the lengua and thus leaving it devoid of any sort of flavor/texture whatsoever. Now I'm very passionate about my beef tongue so perhaps it's not in anyone's best interest to take what I say about this burrito au pied de la lettre, but this burrito managed to betray every expectation about the noblest cut of the beef: whereas I expected a succulent, juicy, flavorful sensation with each bite, all I got was a mushy, watery concoction that was overpowered by the overly generous flavor of cheese.

Besides from the disappointing lengua burrito, the chips they gave me were the super greasy home-fried kind, which I imagine might be a plus for some and a huge gaping minus for others including myself, and their pathetic excuse for a salsa bar only had four choices: salsa verde, not-so-spicy red salsa, pico de gallo and another thing that I cannot remember at this point.

Despite all their shortcomings, their food is surprisingly affordable (6.95 for a super burrito) which, in my opinion, is the only thing preventing me from giving this place a one star review. Since I was a little intoxicated when I tried this place and out of the virtue that this place is only 2.5 blocks away from where I live, I'll give this place another try on my next drunken escapade, but I know when I've been thoroughly disappointed and betrayed and this experience came mighty close to it.
author: Scott S.

description: Steak and prawn burrito for 7 or 8 bucks before 2 am always sounds good after the bars until Sunday morning rolls around. Good place though. Cheaper than papalote. Try putting papalote salsa on their burritos.
author: Marty J.

description: The food here is amazing. Strawberry agua fresca is to die for! Classic Mexican food.
author: Jenna K.

description:
Came here after the candy bar, since a few of my friends were hungry.

We all shared nachos and some of us ordered the carne asada tacos for $2.55.  The meat didn't taste fresh, but what stood out was the self serve salsa bar.  

I did cringe when one of the staff dropped a plate and it broke/shattered next to me. OUCH,. i guess no apologies?    

This place is best for take out and more for drunken night munchies.  If I had more to drink, I would have probably rated this 3 stars.  

Will not be back!
author: Chanel L.

description: One of the best mexican food in this area. When I get off work i like to stop by and order a burrito once in a while since its on my way home. It always taste the same and thats good for me I don't like an odd burrito like othere places on this street. I come here with no hesitation.
author: Anthony G.

description:
Carne Asada California Burrito is amazing.
Ya, french fries, carne, cheese and guacamole is pretty damn good.

Nice salsa bar as well
author: James B.

description: I love this place! I grew up on Tex-Mex and lived in LA for 7 years, and every time I come here I'm transported back to my roots. Hits home in the best way, especially with the taco de lengua and the super well-priced burrito. As a chips and salsa connoisseur, the salsas and options are all excellent, including salsa ranchera muy picante! Plus, Judy always has a wonderfully friendly smile on her face. Been here many times and will be back again!
author: Jared S.

description: I love this restaurant!  The best burrito I've ever eaten in SF.  Staff is very friendly and always welcome customers. And Yes!  Free chips and Salsa Bar. Very nice!
author: Parinamana M.

description: Had the best chicken Burrito ever! Everything in the burrito tasted great. Their Guacamole is amazing too. Tried so many Mexican places in SF but this one is the best.
author: Arta S.

description: I loved the chicken BBQ super taco. Was really delicious. Almost prompted a friend to move here from NY. Was pretty darn impressed by the tastiness.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Came in last night, Sunday November 25th, 2012 - and ordered the Grilled Vegetables Burrito for $6.45 along with a can of coke and was offered free chips for the salsa bar.

The burrito was filled with grilled vegetables - but fell apart due to the weight which is one of my biggest complaints with a burrito as I prefer to hold it rather than eat it with a fork and knife.

I would try it again if in the area - however, I wouldn't make a special trip for it.
author: Brian D.

description: This place is fast, delicious and cheap. These are three qualities I look for in a Mexican place. I don't know what they do to their burritos, but they come out great. They give a generous portion on the chips, and have a good selection at the salsa bar. All around, a great quick place to grab a very satisfying burrito.
author: Steve A.

description:
The quality of meat served here is the WORST I have ever seen at a Taqueria, and for some reason I have been stupid enough to try them all. 

Carne Asada - dog food
Pollo Asada - 0% white meat.  Nasty cartilage and bone pieces everywhere.
Carnitas - fatty, greasy, with big chunks of rubbery pork skin. 
Al Pastor - gritty with shocking amounts of orange grease

That being said, my wife always gets a bean and cheese burrito here and is pleased - and the salsa bar is pretty solid.  So if you must come here to fulfill a burrito craving, stick with a vegetarian burrito - TRUST ME.
author: Dan L.

description: Went on the first day El Rancho opened and I was pleasantly surprised. Prices are standard and food quality was high - I ordered an al pastor taco and it was delicious. Quantity was great, also. The space is clean and nicely renovated. Definitely an improvement on the previous establishment!
author: Nikolas M.

description: Burritos are HUGE!  Not even close to being my fav place at ALL, but the only reason I'm giving it 3 instead of 4 is because there is a wide selection of tortillas you can choose from.  I don't know if the taste makes THAT much of a difference, but I think it's cool...
author: Jennifer L.

description:
The food isn't amazing, but it get's the job done when you need that Mexican fix at 12am midnight- burritos are big, filling and will knock you out.  I'm not a regular, but have been here a couple times and have no complaints.  Yes, it isn't a Papalote, but then again why would anyone expect it to be?

The ladies who work the counter are always nice and pleasant.
author: Clarissa P.

description: I believe every restaurant has a niche dish that you keep coming back to.  Sometimes you have to discover it by customizing, sometimes you discover it by accident.  This place is your typical taco shop, being mexican i can't order anything straight from their menu and be happy with the obscene amounts of cheese, sour cream and "pico de gallo" in their burritos.  So, here's what you need to order, any of the burritos but ask for refried beans and guacamole only, no cheese, no sour cream, and no rice.  Think about it, growing up poor we didn't have money for cheese or sour cream, and rice was often reserved for special occasions.  In other words, if you'd like to eat what the common folk in Mexico eat, which is effing delicious stick to the fewest ingredients possible, you can thank me later.
author: Roberto Z.

description:
humongous sized burrito with juicy chicken.

nice folks and super fast as I paid at the cashier, glanced at the lunatic yelling outside the 24 stop, poured a cup of water, gal behind counter asked if i'd like chips...i said si' por favor

grabbed some pico at the salsa bar, sat down, tuned out the obnoxious car salesman wearing a crown on telemundo, opened up sf weekly and went straight to naughty section then felt someone hover over me handing me the foiled burrito in a red basket all in a matter of 5 minutes

walked out of there stuffed! not bad for a $6.80 regular burrito this side of market
author: Clark G.

description: This is a great neighborhood taqueria: cheap, tasty, convenient, and not pretentious! On a recent trip, I had the fried fish taco, carnitas taco, and al pastor taco. The fish taco was yummy and had a bunch of salsas/toppings (though the fish piece could have been a little bigger). The al pastor was incredible - probably the best I've had. The carnitas was great as well. The meat was all well-seasoned.
author: J L.

description: Super Pollo burrito was great.   Big size,  they grilled the tortilla,  salsa was spicy.   Place is clean and the price was less than $8, where a lot of other places are $10+.  I'll be back.
author: Barry Z.

description:
After a few unpleasant altercations with a burrito at this particular taqueria I decided to steer clear. Like any other unsatisfying relationship you try and make it work cuz it's convenient. Hours (only 2am last call on Divis), location (close), price (cheap) make it too easy fall back on. But I took a stand and said no more. 

Until last night. I heard she'd changed. Apparently the tacos were really good. Maybe I'd misjudged. Not given it time. So I decided I couldn't ignore her anymore. But goddamn it I'm gonna take it slow. I got a carnitas taco ($2.79). Simple. I was surprised at how much I enjoyed it. Now I'm hopeful. I may be ready for the super taco ($4) sooner than I think.
author: Quentin J.

description:
Wandering through NoPa and wondering where you can get food that isn't $20 for a "small plate meant for sharing"? I'm talking real food, the kind will actually fill you up.

Times are rough in this neighborhood for the pragmatic, with the continuing closure of affordable dining options in the area and the "remodeling" of others (resulting in swank atmosphere, handcrafted drinks and a sudden doubling of prices on the menu items). Thank goodness for El Rancho Grande, one of the few remaining places keeping it authentic, affordable, and real in our neighborhood.

They have a huge menu, and their fish tacos are the best I've had without the need to be deep fried or drenched in cheese/sour cream for flavor. (Of course, there are plenty of items on the menu that are more unhealthy if you're so inclined). They aren't the best Mexican place in SF by any means, but they are friendly, the menu items extensive and delicious, open late, family-owned/run and....a much needed part of the NoPa neighborhood.
author: Jeffrey P.

description: I go here after work at least once a week I love their shrimp and carne asada burrito its meat is so savory and always tastes great.
author: Javier G.

description:
A staple since it's so near my place. I come here when I'm too lazy to walk over to Little Chihuahua. The flavors lack that certain kick, but they do offer lengua and cabeza as meat options. Also, the chimichanga is a steal for the amount of food you get.

Favorites: Chimichanga; lengua, cabeza, and chorizo meat options, chile verde sala
author: Kai C.

description:
Cheap, fast, and easy.  Never had a problem here and come pretty regularly.  It's not the best mexican place in the world but serves up a serviceable meal at a very reasonable price given the NOPA location.  

Also, they have a whole wheat tortilla's and a solid variety of non-meat options which is always nice.
author: Max C.

description:
One of my favorite Taquerias in the city. Good flavorful food, great salsa bar, and open late. What more can you want?

Also, as a San Diegan, I appreciate that they do the California Burrito right: lots of fries, lots of guacamole, and tasty carne. Oh plus they make the tortillas fresh so they're always warm and wonderful.

Recommend: California Burrito or Tacos.
author: Tis T.

description: Best burrito in SF. Try the super burrito with chicken on a tomato tortilla. Or the California burrito with chicken on garlic tortilla.
author: Michael S.

description:
I've been here a handful of times. I've never had anything that makes me want to go back. I still don't know why I do. It's great for those "Damn, I'm craving some shitty Mexican food right now!" kinda days.

This is a less than stellar taco/burrito shop. I had to call in sick on Monday cause of the food I ate Sunday night. Carnitas quesadilla. -4

It's one of the few places to eat that's open late on Divis. +1
author: Harold C.

description: This little place is great!! Had a friend visiting from out of town and after walking around the city we were looking for food! Happened across this place and so glad we did. It is cheap good Mexican food!! Delicious wet burritos and amazing quesadillas for my friend!! This place has a great location, very clean, and the staff was friendly and prompt. Would definitely recommend to others! Yummm!!! :)
author: K W.

description: Well 1st off all the restaurant itself is literally right behind a bus stop. My 1st and last time coming here. They have no space. A tv in the corner with an ATM in in the one room. I ordered the wet burrito.   Which is a burrito. With sauce on top(it was okay) thankfully it wasn't soggy:) the guacamole wasn't good. Lengua (tongue ) however was good. While I was eating there a pidgin flew it. I found it gross. And extremely unsanitary. If your starving and on the run. Run away from here. I'm sure a burger or taco truck would be quicker n faster. Food is okay. Ambiance not so much. Hope this helps:)
author: Martin M.

description: two years later after the food poisoning incident i decided to give el rancho another chance. i had the free lunch offer from the go pago app, so this time i ordered the cheesesteak lunch combo with fries and soda.  no mexican food. it was dericious.  they hired new staff.
author: Pickle R.

description:
My first favorite burrito outside of the mission. Grilled vegetables and tasty rice and beans for about $6. Free chips and tasty salsa to boot!

I highly recommend this place.
author: Stephanie D.

description: Suuuuper legit. Best burritos in the neighborhood. Really friendly staff. FAST service, order a burrito and it's ready before you've even loaded up your salsa cups!
author: Carolyn C.

description: Solid neighborhood taqueria. If it were somewhere else besides SF, I might give it 4 stars. I particularly liked the choice of tortillas and the fresh salsa bar with the most delicious grilled jalapenos I've ever tasted. I wasn't so crazy about the sandy shrimp in my burrito. I'd definitely go back here and try something else.
author: Brett W.

description: Good quality food at a great price. Friendly Mexican atmosphere!
author: Julian C.

description: HUGE burrito for around $7-8. I got the carnitas super burrito & it was so good. The carnitas was cooked perfectly - probably the best shredded pork I've had. They weren't stingy with the meat or anything else. I really loved everything about this place. They also have a nice little salsa bar. The red salsa is the best!
author: Junel S.

description:
This place is a little pricey but it's like 200 ft from my house and it tastes good. That's the reason I go. Also the people are friendly and there's hardly ever a crowd there. 

The green salsa is SABROSO! One of these days I might try their American faire which includes a cheesesteak which I'm not so sure about but maybe if I was already drunk it might work. 

I like this place.
author: Alex O.

description:
Finally, a decent (and decently priced) taqueria within easy walking distance of my flat.  

No, we don't need another "Mexican-inspired" or a-lot-of-people-are-drinking-cheap-beer-there-so-its-food-must-be-good or new-take-on-comfort-food or Flexican or any other ridiculous excuse to overcharge people for small food portions in this neighborhood.  After seven years of living here, I now realize that San Francisco gentrification comes in many forms, and one of its most insidious is the restaurant that spends (and charges) a lot of money in order to mask its pretentiousness.

El Rancho Grande is not pretentious.  It doesn't pretend or strive (or cleverly negate the claim) to be anything that it's not.  It doesn't consider itself revolutionary, evolutionary, devolutionary, or any other pomo "ary."  It's a Mission taqueria located right here in the Western Addition.

Is it amazing?  Not by a long shot, but being able to avoid riding the 22 just to eat a decent burrito is worth a taste-and-quality tradeoff.
author: John S.

description: I live in the neighborhood and this is my go to take out spot. My favorite are the lengua super burritos. They have delicious agua fresca. The food is fresh and is made quickly. Their super tacos are huge and are plenty of food for a full meal.
author: M L.

description:
Veggie nachos!! Nom nom nom! Just remember to ask for black beans, otherwise you get re-fried... unknown whether or not their re-fried are veggie friendly. 
Decent prices. Fast, friendly enough service. The place is clean and spacious. Free convenient and cold water at the counter. 
I have only been twice so far, will have to write more when after going back a few times.
author: joanna r.

description: Open really late, which is awesome since most places in the area are not. They are really fast and have an extensive menu, the burritos are huge!
author: Kelso H.

description:
Alright...

DON'T GO HERE MY WALLET GOT STOLEN IN UNDER 20 MINUTES BY THE CASHIER.

So I went there yesterday afternoon and ordered the mushroom and cheese quesadilla. It was good, I was a bit high and walked away from the restaurant without my wallet, I freaked out and my friend and I turned around and went back. The table had been cleared off...and my wallet was gone. Now there was NO ONE in the resturant, except me and my two friends and an old couple came in while we were there.

I went back and left them with my number, decided to call today to see if someone had turned in my wallet. A women answered (the same women who had taken my order and CLEARED THE TABLE) and when I told them I was calling about my missing wallet she immediately started mumbling and acting nervous. I asked to speak to a manager, to which I was told "there wasn't one". I asked her again, because come on...theres no manager? Really. 

The women became completely unhelpful and I doubt she gave my information to a manager. I will be calling them back later but BE WARNED!
author: Bea H.

description:
Took me a week to come here after it opened because it looked so generic & unappealing, even though it's less than 1 block from my apartment.

But once I realized this place has really good carnitas, chips, and salsa, I came back 3 times within 24 hours. 

Chips are delicious restaurant-style. The salsa bar has 3 salsas. I never go for pico de gallo, but the verde and red smooth salsas are excellent. I prefer El Rancho's more classic Tex-Mex garlicky tomato salsa to Papalote's orange stuff, but I could see how you'd go the other way. Sometimes they have roasted jalapenos which are delish. Never tried the pickled mix. 

(And to finish off the comparison of all chips & salsa in Nopa, Green Chile's red salsa sucks as do their out-of-a-bag blue chips. Little Chihuahua has decent chips that I think are good-quality-bagged and a nice selection in their salsa bar, 2-3 of which are very good, but not as addictive as El Rancho's. I'm not sure how you even get a bowl of salsa at Nopalito, but they have a weird yet awesome baked salsa & chips app. Papalote's salsa is excellent with its own cult following, and it's chips are sometimes decent restaurant-style and sometimes bagged-gross.)

I had a carne asada taco once. Decent,  but Papalote's carne asada is better.

Star lost for: slow service, chile relleno that was too drowned in cheese & sauce, inferior carne asade to the neighborhood fav, no bean selection beyond refried pinto (or at least I wasn't offered any).

But the carnitas, chips, and salsa still make it 4 stars. And it's open until midnight weeknights, 2am weekends!
author: Jessica J.

description:
SUPER good. I ordered the special mojado with carnitas. It was HUGE and delicious. I ate here at about 3:30pm and the burrito was so big that I didn't even need dinner that night! Often times at Mexican restaurants I don't care too much for the chips they give you but at this place they were verrrrrry good with the perfect amount of saltiness. I also got one of the glass bottle coke which are always the best. I dealt with 2 of the workers and both of them were really friendly. 

Can't go wrong with this place. Very clean and a nice atmosphere as well. If I were in the area I definitely wouldn't hesitate on going back. 


My absolute ONLY complaint is that I got a few pieces of tough meat. That's bound to happen though.
author: Randy C.

description:
Good veggie burrito, damn good avo/salsa mix, great service and fairly inexpensive

Also perfect chips, atta babe
author: Dylan S.

description:
Man this place is tasty.  I can only imagine how long it'll take me to get on a first-name-basis with the staff.  The place is great for the 'hood, we've been lacking a solid taqueria.  Don't get me wrong, Green Chile rocks my world, but that's going for a unique theme with the whole New Mexico thing.  Papalote is good, followed up by the Little Chihuahua, but they're trying to do that whole gourmet/expensive/white-people thing.  El Rancho Grande is a classic taqueria that's not trying to be anything more than that.

The food is excellent, super fresh and well-priced.  The salsa bar is minimal, but crucial.  They have all the standards and on one of the two times I've been there they had grilled jalapenos... nice!  They have a super tasty jabanero salsa but you have to ask for it due to it spoiling while it sits out because no one eats it.  It just makes me so sad to see good hot sauce go to waste like that.  DON'T BE AFRAID OF THE HEAT PEOPLE!!!

So if you live in the 'hood, or your going to a show or getting some drinks or something and you're looking for something good, affordable and quick, do yourself a favor and stop by El Rancho Grande.  You won't regret it.
author: Ian M.

description: Just opened my burrito and was reaching for a chip when a fat ass roach crawled out of it.... really guys I don't want my money back,  but people don't go there it can't be good for your health.
author: Ben M.

description:
Cheap, huge portions, super friendly.
Clean salsa bar. 
Would give 'em 5 but the place is not quite to the level of papalote or 25th + mission taqueira.
author: Jordan S.

description:
Steak and Prawn Burrito! Get after it!

This place is straight up Taqueria. Great to-go place.

You know how sometimes you don't want to hear some experimental indie rock? You just want straight to the face, don't bore us, get to the chorus? This is like that. But a Taqueria.
author: Anthony C.

description:
Avoid at all costs...unless you feel like spending the entire next day on the toilet.

This temptress tastes great on the way down, especially after a show at the Indy, but beware - the following 24 hours will be filled with frequent trips to the bathroom.  And this is not just from personal experience, but friends have been having the same issues
author: JJ O.

description:
No, it's not the very best as Mission-style joints go, but it is in our 'hood, finally and a welcome addition after the chi-chi, overpriced Papalote and Green Chile Kitchen.  I mean, c'mon! pushing 10 bucks for a goddamn burrito is just rotten. 
Anyway, the food here is just fine, the staff are real nice and you can even get desayuno anytime. 5 stars just for doing the right thing.
author: Phillip M.

description: I love this place !! I try to come here 2/3 times a week because its that good !!! I love that the salsa bar has an amazing Habanero Salsa , but not only that it  also has an amazing Guac salsa as well , and you only know if you are from the southwest that this is an awesome standard !!!! Try the quesadillas because they are Awesome !!! and you have from like 4 different tortilla types to choose from !! Spinach, Wheat, Garlic and  Flour !!! :) Thanks El Rancho !!! I know your locals love you and I do too even though I live at Park Merced !!! :)
author: Javier G.

description:
This place must be somehow affiliated with a favorite of mine, El Castillito on Church.  The salsa verde, tortilla prep and rice seasoning are all the exact same.  

This place is cheap and goodies, but the service is way too slow to be a viable grab and git option.  You expect super slow service at Chihuahua, Green Chile and Papalote, but this place should be differentiating itself with speed and value.  It's close.  They should definitely remove the burgers from the menu - it sends the wrong message and i'm sure no one orders them anyway.  

Solid effort that should hopefully speed up over time.
author: Matt S.

description:
This place opened super close to my old house (I moved last month) and it was a revelation in a way. I was just glad to get a pretty darn good Mex food place wo having to walk to the Haight or (obviously) the Mission. 

WHAT I ALWAYS GET: The GRILLED VEGGIE BURRITO. Yum Yum Yum. Cheap ($5) and feels health(ish)
author: Perry S.

description:
For a local Taqueria this place is worthy of 3-star. It's really just A-OK, as Yelp puts it.

It's food is more safe then truly flavorful, and their portions are big rather then tasty. Then again this is the only taco place located on Divis in that area, so it's kind of got the area to itself. 

IMHO there are many really good taqueria places around town, including taco trucks, that put this place to shame. Then again if it's 2am and you're wondering out of Minibar next door, I can certainly see the appeal.

Overall, if you need your burrito fix and you're on foot, this place will do in a pinch. If you're craving the ultimate mexican taco truck like experience, go elsewhere.
author: Erik B.

description: I begrudgingly love El Rancho Grande.  While Little Chiuaua gets most of the attention in our hood, I am always drawn to El Rancho, and order there more often than not.  It's simply a good mexican food at a reasonable price.
author: Nick M.

description: Horrible food. Just finished ordering some nachos.. Everything tastes like it comes from a can, the beans,  the tomatoes in the salsa.. Low grade Mexican food. Couldn't even finish eating our plate.. And cashier wasn't friendly at all, she was texting the whole time we were ordering.
author: Brenda R.

description:
I live literally three blocks away from this place and I keep going back. Their super burrito is totally on par with most of the Mexican places in SF. I alternate between their vegetarian and chicken. The guacamole, as usual, makes the burrito great.

Overall, they do a really good job mixing the ingredients to the right proportions. The rice is never over/undercooked, the beans are always flavored well, and the tortilla never over toasted.

I like to stay with the burrito. I've also had the mushroom quesadilla, which was jammed packed with cheese and mushrooms, though I have to say it was a little too overwhelming for my taste buds and perhaps digestives system.

Plus, like all great Mexican joints, there's always FUTBOL playing in the background.
author: Terry H.

description:
I'm very happy to have a good burrito place right in the hood.  This is not the "best" burrito in the city but I have not one bad experience so not sure where all of the bad reviews are coming from.

There are lots of authentic options and fresh juices too. The grilled chicken is very good and the home made salsa's are excellent as well.  Very nice people.  

They do not have a bean and cheese burrito on the menu, which is what I get for my kids. They are always happy to make it but never sure what to charge.
author: don M.

description:
I stepped out of Mini Bar a few doors down and noticed that the new burrito shop had finally opened.  Thrilled, I stepped in and ordered two chili verde tacos, which were spectacular.  The salsa bar is stocked with very fresh tasting salsas, and the chips are great.  

The next night I went for a burrito and again had chiliverde as it was so great the night before.  My new favorite burrito, in a city with so much competition for that title.  

I was going to start a fast today, but I'm going to have to work through the menu here for a few days first........
author: Michael S.

description:
Surprised to read reviews about how bad the place was (bones in burritos, bad quality meats, etc.).  Luckily, I hadn't read any of these when I stopped by to fix my carnitas burrito fix.

IMO, standard fare, quick turnaround, friendly service, reasonable prices.  There are some great burrito places nearby so hopefully they can work out the kinks but my experience here was pleasant.
author: F. P.

description:
I had a carnitas burrito mojado and it was probably the worst burrito I've had in San Francisco.  I'm glad to have a taqueria down the block, and I'll give it another try sometime when I don't want to walk more than a block for a burrito.  Every other burrito place in the neighborhood (Green Chile, Papalote, Little Chihuahua) is worth the walk.

Extra star for the salsa bar, a nice touch.
author: Kat W.

description:
It's no SoCal mexican food, but the portions where big and there is finally a decent mexican food place that is near my house. Overall, San Francisco has not impressed my palate in regards to mexican food, but stick with mission if you want something closer to the real deal. 

This is more for a quick grab when you're craving it.
author: Riley B.

description:
Seriously, if anyone out there is willing (even in a drunk stupor) to accept this as a viable Mexican Taqueria, they need to move back to what ever shit hole town they came from.

Low quality ingredients, flavorless food, down-right disgusting salsa bar (think Pace Picante) and you've earned yourself a permanent boycott in my book. I've been here over a dozen times, and it's progressively gotten worse and worse. There burritos are like a big, luke warm wrap of sawdust drenched in spoiled beef grease. While I've never gotten full-blown food poisoning, me as well as many other locals have gotten queezy after ingesting their gruel.

I HOPE the owner reads this and takes heed. Sure, drunken Marina adventure seekers ("Divisadero is so edgy") may gobble down your slop after the bars close, but I would think you'd care about the quality of the food attached to your name!

Do yourself a favor and go to Pancho Villa, El Toro, Cancun, etc, etc, etc...See what others are doing RIGHT that you are CLEARLY not. Maybe court the one of the aforementioned establishment's daughter's and probe her for recipes and secrets. I don't know what else to say, other than I prefer corner store burrito's to yours.

It's only a matter of time until an actual REAL Taqueria catches wind of he potential business and opens along Divisadero. At that point your business will be heading for the big Rancho Grande in the sky.
author: Honest T.

description:
We came here craving some burritos, and left having eaten some "super sized" burritos that filled our tummies. Despite having a full stomach upon our leave, though, we felt the place overall was only okay.

We ordered two super burritos, one with BBQ chicken and the other carne asada. Neither was particularly great, the carne asada in particular was a little disappointing, but both were okay. Because we decided to eat there, we also got complimentary chips. The chips, while not super fresh, were decent. They also had a well stalked salsa bar, although the freshly chopped salsa was way too watery.

All in all, we were satisfied, but some of the problems were a little too glaring for the overall experience and because of that it's doubtful we will be back.
author: Sami R.

description:
Came in here the other day for lunch.  They have a decent salsa bar with 4 types of salsa, verde being the best. Added points for having grilled jalapenos, grilled onions, regular jalapenos and limes. Chips a little lacking but not horrendous as I dont think they were fresh.

Pretty expansive menu w/ full plates, tacos, tortas, etc. They serve beer but apparently not by itself. Pretty large TV in the corner that should usually have on some type of soccer.

I ordered the regular pollo asado burrito, good size, good taste. Meat was done quite well, not too much rice. Definitely better than Gordos or Pancho's on Geary.

Regular burrito was decent price at 6.80 including tax. Tacos are not super cheap at $2.50 ea especially since I usually get $1.50 tacos down the Peninsula by my work but still a good deal. A plus is that they are open until 2 on Fri and Sat and 12 every other night.

All in all I would eat here again tomorrow.
author: Andrew C.

description: This place is great.  I go here on Thursday nights periodically with a group of 10 to 12 friends.  The service is splendid, fast, and they never make mistakes.  We all get our food very quickly and there is plenty of room for us to sit together.  The prices are good and you get very large portions.  They give us free chips and salsa, so we are never tired of waiting for our meal to come.
author: Carlos P.

description: I really like this place. More authentic than Chihuahua, yet not quite the same salsa selection. They used to have roasted whole peppers at the salsa bar which is always good. Good specials and a great location for a taqueria.
author: Paul Y.

description: A go-to for NOPA residents. I had an al pastor burrito that wasn't too impressive, but their California burrito is pretty solid (for NorCal). Tacos are enormous; too much for the two tortillas they give you. Ask for a third.
author: Travis S.

description: My staple place as of late.  Good prices, good but not great quality, good quantity, and lots of great salsa from the salsa bar.  Nothing overly special but in my opinion better than Papalote. ~$7 for a burrito.
author: Evan M.

description: This place used to be awesome. I'm not sure what happened though because recently it sucks. Maybe they hired new people and didn't train them properly. The tables are always filthy and sticky now. The fat girl at the register has a bad attitude and messed up my wife's order then gave her a hard time about it. The California burrito I had today was the worst one I've ever had. The tortilla was burned and stale. The meat was full of gristle and I had to spit out chunks of meat I couldn't chew constantly. Seems like this is a trend for restaurants on Divisadero St, they get super popular because of all the damn hipsters and then they start to suck till they go outa business.
author: Morgan M.

description: 5 stars for awesome food for the price, nice people working there, open late,and  awesome location. One of my favorite hole in the wall places.
author: Paige G.

description: Everything in my burrito was cold. They didn't even bother to put warm beans in it. Most disappointing burrito I've ever ordered. Good thing this area has so many other options!
author: Katie M.

description:
My impression is that I'm not overwhelmed or underwhelmed.  The food was better than 'meh, but pretty much 'meh.

After weeks of waiting the place opened and so we had to give it a try.  Wanting to try a lot of different things my husband and I ordered this stuff to go:

Super Carna Asada Taco
Chicken Tostada
Fish Taco
Chicken Flautes
Super Steak Quesadilla

The steak taco was a sloppy mess in a box.  I had to eat 2/3 of it in order to pick up the corn tortillas and bite into it.  The flavor was delicious.  I'm thinking steak burrito would be much better.

The tostada was again, a sloppy mess to the point I had no idea what it was.  And the shell was not crispy, and had  probably never actually been fried..seemed like a corn tortilla just layed down and layered with slop...tasty slop.  I did have one of those unfortunate bites of chicken that seemed to be bone, grizzle, muscle, or something tough.  I poked around for about four bites then straight up gave up.  I won't recommend any of it.

The fish taco was not bad, but after two bites I found myself wondering if my dog might like a taste of the fish.  Not a good sign.  

My husband thought the flautas were excellent.  My only warning is that they are smothered.  So if you get them to go, either plan to eat them quickly or ask for the guacamole, pico, and sour cream to be on the side.

His review of the super steak quesadilla is "It was pretty good."  

The flavor is there.  I think, because everything seemed so sloppy, this place will be best for burritos and hopefully enchiladas.  (fingers crossed)
author: Jessica B.

description: Wow! Just went to this place because it next-door to another stop I had to make.  I got a super chicken burrito and was very tasty.
author: Matt B.

description: I ate a damn good burrito tonight from here. It was PACKED with chicken, beans, cheese, lettuce, guac, sour cream, etc. But literally packed in a way that it was almost hard to eat. It was almost so hard to eat that it kept falling apart and was super messy. By the time I got the last 5th section it fell apart completely and I couldn't put it back together. That part ended up in the trash. Maybe a fork would be wise next time! It was super good though, and huge...if I was given more foil it could've been used as a second meal. Everything else about this joint was fine, except for the fact that the television was blasting. I couldn't even hear my own self think over the volume. But that's not a legitimate complaint, because like I said the food made up for it.
author: Sonya D.

description: OMG this place is so good, after the first time I went there I called 12 people to tell them I had found the best food for under $10 in San Francisco. You should also know that not only am I SUPER picky and I always want some sort of substitution, my daughter is even worse than me. They place is also very clean and the people are really nice!!!!!!!!!!
author: Shannon E.

description: This place was nearly empty when I walked in tonight.  You know what that means?  It means you can get in here before it comes the next big thing.  I ordered a carnitas burrito mojado here this evening, and I've got to say, having eaten in taquerias all over California and Texas, the carnitas are among some of the best I've ever had.  Sure this neighborhood already has green chile and little chihuahua, but up until this point we've not had a proper traditional taqueria.    Reminds me quite a bit of El Castillo.  Good horchata too!  All I can say is after tonight I'll be a regular and you'd be a damned fool if you aren't as well.
author: Joshua W.

description: I have only ordered the prawn burrito here but every time it's a tasty prawn party in my mouth. I love how they butterfly the prawns so they are super succulent and it seems like you are getting more prawns in every bite! Also, I really like the number of prawns they give u-- usually places will skimp out and hardly give u any.  You get a bite o' prawn in almost every burrito bite here. I also like how they put a little cheese and sour cream but they usually don't overdo it. El Rancho Grande is hands down the best place to get a prawn burrito in SF.
author: M L.

description: Best horchata I have ever had.  Tostada salad scarfed it down. Tortilla crispy and golden brown. Salsa Verde rules.
author: Bill T.

description: Unspectacular, BUT definitely solid. The menu is huge, & the portions are ridiculous. This is arguably the most cost-effective meal in the 'hood these days. One super chicken taco at $3.50 is about as big as a super chicken burrito at $7 at most other places. Again, the food is not going to blow your mind, but it's definitely better than passable. So what, it's not gourmet. Nopalito is a few blocks away. Take a walk or put a little hot sauce on it & deal.
author: Pete J.

description: This might be the worst Mexican place I've ever been to in San Francisco. Aside from the carnitas being highly over-seasoned, fatty and lukewarm, my first bite was complimented by a giant bone shard. The rice was drier than a (or rather, the) bone, the salsa tasted old and sickly sweet (why!?),  and the guacamole was worse than that Guacamole Dip you buy at the store that's really just green sour cream. To top the whole thing off, the tortilla had so much shortening in it, I could see straight through it. Really, I could have used it as plastic wrap. What a miserable experience. I'd rather eat a bum's discarded Taco Bell remnants. If you care about your happiness in any way, shape or form, do not eat here.
author: Andy N.

description: This one time, I was NOT sober and I REALLY needed a 'rrito. That's pretty much where the story ends. Thanks guys... and cashier chick with great nails.
author: Kiki C.

description: Not bad.  Pretty good flavors.  The chicken taco has a nice freshness to it with onions, cilantro and tomatoes.  The fish taco is good.  Again very flavorful.
author: Frank M.

description: This place is fast, good, and cheap.  Love it.  The chips are amazing, and I love the green salsa.
author: Liz A.

description: The Ranchie Grande deserves Zero stars.  I'm an SF local --favorite Mexican food El Farilito, Cancun, Tommy's Mexican, and Underdog's Taco Shop, Burrito Express.  I love Mexican food.  Usually, I'll even be happy with bad Mexican food, but this is the most sick demented plot devised by mankind.   Someone put a what looks like a Mexican taqueria right across the street from my apartment in a neighborhood void of late night mexican food.  Inside you will even find chips and salsa that aren't too bad, but the meat (I've tried steak, chicken, and Carnitas) and beans are disgusting. I gave this place three tries hoping that I was being over judgmental or that I got a bad batch, but each time I stopped myself halfway through and had to throw it out.
author: mick H.

description: For all you San Diego kids now living in the city, this place has a very acceptable California burrito. No joke. After many let downs trying "California burritos" at other taco shops, I am so happy I found this place! I haven't tried anything else on the menu, but I'm sure it's all good. If you haven't tried a California burrito, do yourself a favor and get one. This is the closest thing to the REAL thing I have been able to find!
author: Nikki M.

description:
So I signed up to Yelp JUST to respond to a few of these reviews.

I live down the street and go here twice a week. Not because it is the BEST Mexican food ever but because it is close and authentic. A few people refer to Little Chihuahua and Green Chile Kitchen as better. Sorry - those are not even in the same category. This is a TAQUERIA - NOT a schmancy SF gourmet mex knock off. Don't get me wrong, I like both of those places but they are NOT the same thing. This place has good, fairly priced, authentic taqueria food. As someone who was born and raised in the Bay Area I have been going to all sorts of Mexican food forever and this place is good enough for the location.

Bottom line - if you are thinking of driving across SF to come here you are better served going to Pancho Villa or somewhere else in the Mission. HOWEVER - if you are leaving the Independent or romping around Divisadero it is the best/most authentic around and is open SUPER late-night(dude even passed me some tacos out the back door one night when they were closed). 

I tend to get the Al Pastor taco/burritto. See you later tonight Rancho Grande!!!
author: Chris M.

description: This place is a dunk munchie sufferer's dream.  Their burritos are insanely satisfying.  You will most likely come back for more after trying it once.  Its hard to find a place like this on divis among the sea of bars and other drinking wholes.
author: Andrew Christian C.

description: This is great local taqueria. I've been a regular since they opened. The staff is super friendly, the service is quick, and the salsa bar is always stocked.  Extra chips would nice!
author: Martin V.

description: FINALLY my gentrified, boring ass neighborhood gets some good cheap eats. By San Francisco standards, this is decent Mexican cheap comida. Open late, good fare and good people. That's what it's all about.  Now If I can talk them into serving Birria, I will be really doing cartwheels.....
author: Tim E.

description: I think the food here has improved since I wrote my last review. The burritos are decent, and the service continues to be friendly.
author: Leslie K.

description:
So this place is AWESOME for what it is... I always get the carnitas super burrito and it's only $7, feeds both my boyfriend and I!  Open super late, and always quick! Friendly cashier who gave us a sample of horchata! We love this little place! Great food and affordable price. 

If you ask for extra chips they will gladly give you more than one bag!
author: Talli L.

description: Pretty darn good.  Food portions are huge, staff is friendly,  and prices are definitely reasonable.  I have been here on three occassions and each is a success.  They offer a very consistent meal with large portions.  The super burritos are huge, not dry and delicious.  The Wet burrito was also a huge portion that probably could feed a family of six from Bangladesh and they would still have left overs for the next day. In addition my co-worker got the fish tacos and she said they were also delicious and cheesy!  The friendly lady that took my order also said that they make their own chips and salsa!  You could definitely taste the difference from other taquerias.  Hasta la vista baby, until we meet again.
author: Hanna A.

description: Solid post-drinking snack spot. Cheap, efficient, and always crowded and open late for all of us with drunk munchies.
author: Lina L.

description: Great neighborhood spot and delicious Mexican food. super nice staff, reasonable prices, and vegetarian beans.
author: Beth S.

description: Some of the best damn tacos in town. I was pleasantly surprised when I walked in when this place first opened. The staff is friendly and the food came out fast. Try the quesadilla suiza. It's huge and very satisfying.
author: AJ R.

description: Haven't been here at length, but it was friendly, bright, and clean when I dropped by at 11PM on Sunday after a show. I got a chorizo super burrito to go and didn't regret it at all. Cheesy and flavorful, a sizeable meal at a very reasonable price.
author: Kelly J.

description: I don't know if it's because I was slightly inebriated or not, but my super burrito was amazing. I also got horchata and I wish it had more cinnamon. It was also small for the price. This place was open pretty late and is perfect after a night of dancing at the Independent down the street.
author: k h.

description:
I love all of the new places opening in this neighborhood and was excited to see another mexican option.

My criteria for a good taqueria are the variety and the originality of the salsa bar, the quality of the meat and the tortilla chips.  I did really like the chips - a little different than the super light one you find most often.  They were small, crispy and salty - really enjoyed them.  The salsa bar was a bit of a disappointment.  Only two options and a pico de gallo.  Neither was especially unique or flavorful and no spicy option.  I also happened to arrive at a time of day where I was scraping the bottom of the salsa dishes while one of the staffers carefully restocked the ketchup packages. (Yes, they serve cheeseburgers and some other non-mexican dishes - I believe in doing one thing and doing it well, but just my opinion.)  The meat quality was average at best - got a couple bad cuts of chicken I had to spit out.  If I go back, I'll definitely go veggie.

In all, it was good.  If Little Chihuahua weren't just a few blocks away, El Rancho Grande would easily satisfy my mexican craving.  But Little Chihuahua has an amazing salsa bar, the highest quality meats I've found in SF (steak - phenomenal!) and yummy chips they always serve warm.  

That said, it was a good burrito and I recommend giving it a try and forming your own opinion on the place.
author: gretchen d.

description: al pastor tacos and carne asada tortas are my go to menu items here...the tortas are good cant be healthy for you and are a mess but i cant stop ordering them.
author: E.W. S.

description: Not as good as the best spots in the Mission but it's open late and even when I'm sober I know I am going to get a lot of food (their quesadillas are HUMONGOUS) and  it's good...for San Francisco.
author: Mike T.

description: Strawberry agua fresco was amazing and fish tacos were absolutely delicious and loaded with fresh fish!!!
author: L B.

description: I had to try it since there was a parking spot right in front of the taqueria and I was driving down the street. It happened to be my lucky day because I was hungry and I was hungry for a pretty tasty taco, which I did order. My brother had the wet burrito wihch looked amaZing and tasted better than it looked. My tacos were very much worth the 2.25 and loved the salsa bar selection offered. They seemed pretty happy to serve me which made my dinner very enjoyable. The place was very clean and organized with many diferent things to try on the menu. I will be a regular there and I would definatly recommend this place. Everything deserves a chance, you gotta try it atleast once!
author: shadi a.

description: This place gets all its points for BEING OPEN LATE! I live near by so my roommates and I just have our cab driver drop us off here instead of at home at the end of a night. I'm pretty sure the food really isn't that good, but when your'e drunk and with friends at 2:00AM on a Fri/Sat, does it matter what the burrito and nachos actually taste like? Great late-night stop when you get those drunk munchies!
author: Janie Y.

description: Gross Gross Gross.  This place is owned by Arabs.  Meat is rotten tasting, very old and they use it until it sells.  Oil used for cooking is rancid---you can taste in the chips.  I had to throw my burrito away--beware, this place will make you sick.
author: John G.

description: I do NOT recommend this place.  My burrito (super veggie), to go was cold and lifeless. Do yourself a favor and walk a few more blocks to either Green Chili Kitchen or Little Chihuahua or Popalote. All three are miles better than this place.
author: JJ S.

description: Very tasty and inexpensive food, nice staff, open late. Standard taqueria fare plus the best Mexican soup I've ever had. Their caldo de cameron is chock-full of veggies and shrimp, and the seasoned clear broth is just flavorful and hot enough to kick a head cold to the curb.
author: Nicole M.

description: "Where's the beef?" Loved that it was near my house....They gave good carne asada and toppings ratio in the burrito when they first opened...I went back and I barely had carne asada...I thought it was just a one time mistake...went just recently again and still no beef :-\ I was a regular and hopefully they change their burrito ratio...so I can come back....this place would have gotten 4 stars :-P Go to OCEAN TAQUERIA down the street...wayyy better.
author: J.B. E.

description: This is a great place to get a massive burrito for under $8 (w/ meat) or $7 (veg).  Up there in taste with Papalote and cheaper, way better than Green Chile (rip off).  Really good - try it out.
author: Dave S.

description: It is hard looking at a sign that says "hot mexican food" while you are eating an ice cold burrito.  I was excited to have a more traditional low-key taqueria in the hood for those times when I just want some quick good mexican food.   I ordered the vegetarian burrito (I'm a meat-eater, but wasn't in the mood) and sat down to wait.  Within a minute, the waitress hands me a burrito.  I was wondering how they could have made it so fast given the 2 people ahead of me, but soon realized that it must have been pre-made.  When I bit into it, it was completely cold in the middle.  My guess is that they had refrigerated the burrito and heated it up once I ordered it.  The burrito was little more than a tortilla stuffed with cold mush and some half-frozen vegetables.  My standards for taquerias aren't too high, but it takes some nerve to charge around $7 for a cold, pre-made burrito in San Francisco.  Definitely the worst I've had in my 8+ years in SF.
author: Tim S.
